**Dissociation** in [chemistry](/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry") and
[biochemistry](/wiki/Biochemistry "Biochemistry") is a general process in
which molecules (or ionic compounds such as [salts](/wiki/Salt_\(chemistry\)
"Salt \(chemistry\)"), or [complexes](/wiki/Complex_\(chemistry\) "Complex
\(chemistry\)")) separate or split into smaller particles such as atoms, ions
or [radicals](/wiki/Radical_\(chemistry\) "Radical \(chemistry\)"), usually in
a reversible manner. For instance, when an [acid](/wiki/Acid "Acid") dissolves
in water, a [covalent](/wiki/Covalent "Covalent") bond between an
[electronegative](/wiki/Electronegative "Electronegative") atom and a hydrogen
atom is broken by [heterolytic fission](/wiki/Heterolytic_fission "Heterolytic
fission"), which gives a proton (H+) and a negative [ion](/wiki/Ion "Ion").
Dissociation is the same as **recombination**.

## Dissociation
constant[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Dissociation constant")]

Main article: [Dissociation constant](/wiki/Dissociation_constant
"Dissociation constant")

For reversible dissociations in a [chemical
equilibrium](/wiki/Chemical_equilibrium "Chemical equilibrium")

    AB ⇌ A + B

the [dissociation constant](/wiki/Dissociation_constant "Dissociation
constant") _K_ a is the ratio of dissociated to undissociated compound

     K a = [ A ] [ B ] [ A B ] {\displaystyle K_{a}=\mathrm {\frac {[A][B]}{[AB]}} } ![K_{a}={\\mathrm  {{\\frac  {\[A\]\[B\]}{\[AB\]}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0d3dea01bcf342d527a9c6cab93a4459d9c49251)

where the brackets denote the equilibrium concentrations of the species.

## Dissociation
degree[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Dissociation degree")]

The dissociation degree is the fraction of original solute molecules that have
dissociated. It is usually indicated by the Greek symbol α. More accurately,
degree of dissociation refers to the amount of solute dissociated into ions or
radicals per mole. In case of very strong acids and bases, degree of
dissociation will be close to 1. Less powerful acids and bases will have
lesser degree of dissociation. There is a simple relationship between this
parameter and the [van 't Hoff factor](/wiki/Van_%27t_Hoff_factor "Van 't Hoff
factor") ** i {\displaystyle i}
![i](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/add78d8608ad86e54951b8c8bd6c8d8416533d20)**.
If the solute substance dissociates into  n {\displaystyle n}
![n](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)
ions, then

    

    

     i = 1 + α ( n − 1 ) {\displaystyle i=1+\alpha (n-1)} ![i=1+\\alpha \(n-1\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6727544fcf66acc52fb8c0d7a05379f9c75656c4)

For instance, for the following dissociation

    

    

    KCl ⇌ K+ \+ Cl−

As  n = 2 {\displaystyle n=2}
![n=2](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a02c8bd752d2cc859747ca1f3a508281bdbc3b34),
we would have that  i = 1 + α {\displaystyle i=1+\alpha } ![i=1+\\alpha
](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6ed9d5504b79e79be975cad562c582a0588f5774)

##
Salts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Salts")]

The dissociation of salts by [solvation](/wiki/Solvation "Solvation") in a
[solution](/wiki/Solution "Solution") like [water](/wiki/Water_\(molecule\)
"Water \(molecule\)") means the separation of the [anions](/wiki/Anion
"Anion") and [cations](/wiki/Cation "Cation"). The salt can be recovered by
[evaporation](/wiki/Evaporation "Evaporation") of the solvent. See also:
[Solubility equilibrium](/wiki/Solubility_equilibrium "Solubility
equilibrium")

An electrolyte refers to a substance that contains free ions and can be used
as an electrically conductive medium. Most of the solute does not dissociate
in a weak electrolyte whereas in a strong electrolyte a higher ratio of solute
dissociates to form free ions.

A weak electrolyte is a substance whose solute exists in solution mostly in
the form of molecules (which are said to be "undissociated"), with only a
small fraction in the form of ions. Simply because a substance does not
readily dissolve does not make it a weak electrolyte. [Acetic
acid](/wiki/Acetic_acid "Acetic acid") (CH3COOH) and [ammonium](/wiki/Ammonium
"Ammonium") (NH4+) are good examples. Acetic acid is extremely soluble in
water, but most of the compound dissolves into molecules, rendering it a weak
electrolyte. Weak bases and weak acids are generally weak electrolytes. In an
aqueous solution there will be some CH3COOH and some CH3COO− and H+.

A strong electrolyte is a solute that exists in solution completely or nearly
completely as ions. Again, the strength of an electrolyte is defined as the
percentage of solute that is ions, rather than molecules. The higher the
percentage, the stronger the electrolyte. Thus, even if a substance is not
very soluble, but does dissociate completely into ions, the substance is
defined as a strong electrolyte. Similar logic applies to a weak electrolyte.
Strong acids and bases are good examples such as HCl, and H2SO4. These will
all exist as ions in an aqueous medium.

##
Gases[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Gases")]

The degree of dissociation in [gases](/wiki/Gases "Gases") is denoted by the
symbol α where α refers to the percentage of gas molecules which dissociate.
Various relationships between Kp and α exist depending on the stoichiometry of
the equation. The example of [dinitrogen tetroxide](/wiki/Dinitrogen_tetroxide
"Dinitrogen tetroxide") (N2O4) dissociating to [nitrogen
dioxide](/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide "Nitrogen dioxide") (NO2) will be taken.

    N2O4 ⇌ 2NO2

If the initial concentration of dinitrogen tetroxide is 1 mole per litre, this
will decrease by α at equilibrium giving, by stoichiometry, 2α moles of NO2.
The [equilibrium constant](/wiki/Equilibrium_constant "Equilibrium constant")
(in terms of pressure) is given by the equation;

     K p = p ( NO 2 ) 2 p ( N 2 O 4 ) {\displaystyle K_{p}={\frac {\ce {p(NO2)^{2}}}{\ce {p(N2O4)}}}} ![{\\displaystyle K_{p}={\\frac {\\ce {p\(NO2\)^{2}}}{\\ce {p\(N2O4\)}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b732347c47c900e2914468095226c6f68cf21a17)

Where p represents the partial pressure. Hence, through the definition of
[partial pressure](/wiki/Partial_pressure "Partial pressure") and using pT to
represent the total pressure and x to represent the mole fraction;

     K p = p T 2 ( x ( NO 2 ) ) 2 p T ⋅ x ( N 2 O 4 ) = p T ( x ( NO 2 ) ) 2 x ( N 2 O 4 ) {\displaystyle K_{p}={\frac {\ce {{p_{T}}^{2}(x(NO2))^{2}}}{\ce {p_{T}\cdot x(N2O4)}}}={\frac {\ce {p_{T}(x(NO2))^{2}}}{\ce {x(N2O4)}}}} ![{\\displaystyle K_{p}={\\frac {\\ce {{p_{T}}^{2}\(x\(NO2\)\)^{2}}}{\\ce {p_{T}\\cdot x\(N2O4\)}}}={\\frac {\\ce {p_{T}\(x\(NO2\)\)^{2}}}{\\ce {x\(N2O4\)}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/44e0362f8f15b36851adb1230b6a76a2f96b7199)

The total number of moles at equilibrium is (1-α)+(2α) which is equivalent to
1+α. Thus, substituting the mole fractions with actual values in term of alpha
and simplifying;

     K p = p T ( 4 α 2 ) ( 1 + α ) ( 1 − α ) = p T ( 4 α 2 ) 1 − α 2 {\displaystyle K_{p}={\frac {\ce {p_{T}(4\alpha ^{2})}}{(1+\alpha )(1-\alpha )}}={\frac {\ce {p_{T}(4\alpha ^{2})}}{1-\alpha ^{2}}}} ![{\\displaystyle K_{p}={\\frac {\\ce {p_{T}\(4\\alpha ^{2}\)}}{\(1+\\alpha \)\(1-\\alpha \)}}={\\frac {\\ce {p_{T}\(4\\alpha ^{2}\)}}{1-\\alpha ^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fd9c2c22b797bcff02e77696e401ce8ccf37785f)

This equation is in accordance with Le Chatelier's Principle. _K_ p will
remain constant with temperature. The addition of pressure to the system will
increase the value of pT so α must decrease to keep _K_ p constant. In fact,
increasing the pressure of the equilibrium favours a shift to the left
favouring the formation of dinitrogen tetroxide (as on this side of the
equilibrium there is less pressure since pressure is proportional to number of
moles) hence decreasing the extent of dissociation α.

## Acids in aqueous
solution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Acids in aqueous solution")]

Main article: [acid dissociation constant](/wiki/Acid_dissociation_constant
"Acid dissociation constant")

The reaction of an acid in water solvent is often described as a dissociation

     HA ↽ − − ⇀ H + + A − {\displaystyle {\ce {HA<=>{H+}+{A^{-}}}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\ce {HA<=>{H+}+{A^{-}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/65573ef6d3a23b3c4e436a74387bbf87d4f0e554)

where HA is a proton acid such as acetic acid, CH3COOH. The double arrow means
that this is an equilibrium process, with dissociation and recombination
occurring at the same time. This implies that the [acid dissociation
constant](/wiki/Acid_dissociation_constant "Acid dissociation constant")

     K a = [ H + ] [ A − ] [ HA ] {\displaystyle K_{\ce {a}}={\ce {\frac {[H^{+}][A^{-}]}{[HA]}}}} ![{\\displaystyle K_{\\ce {a}}={\\ce {\\frac {\[H^{+}\]\[A^{-}\]}{\[HA\]}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2336c8a3765ce089428093d9cdc295e264635dee)

However a more accurate description is provided by the [Brønsted–Lowry
acid–base theory](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsted%E2%80%93Lowry_acid%E2%80%93base_theory
"Brønsted–Lowry acid–base theory"), which specifies that the _proton_ H+ does
not exist as such in solution but is instead _accepted_ by (bonded to) a water
molecule to form the [hydronium](/wiki/Hydronium "Hydronium") ion H3O+.

The reaction is therefore more correctly written as

     HA + H 2 O ↽ − − ⇀ H 3 O + + A − {\displaystyle {\ce {{HA}+H2O<=>{H3O+}+A^{-}}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\ce {{HA}+H2O<=>{H3O+}+A^{-}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d3d995ec86054f6baf2b28689807af6b49a64423)

and better described as an _ionization_ or formation of ions (for the case
when HA has no net charge). The equilibrium constant is then

     K a = [ H 3 O + ] [ A − ] [ HA ] {\displaystyle K_{\ce {a}}={\ce {\frac {[H_{3}O^{+}][A^{-}]}{[HA]}}}} ![{\\displaystyle K_{\\ce {a}}={\\ce {\\frac {\[H_{3}O^{+}\]\[A^{-}\]}{\[HA\]}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/118a77c4dd2a3573219844c4435c9a442315e5a0)

where  [ H 2 O ] {\displaystyle {\ce {[H_{2}O]}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\ce
{\[H_{2}O\]}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a82766ea0d41424490851cec3f8c03ee294ca8db)
is not included because in dilute solution the solvent is essentially a pure
liquid with a [thermodynamic activity](/wiki/Thermodynamic_activity
"Thermodynamic activity") of one.[1] Ka is variously named a _dissociation
constant_ ,[2] an _acid ionization constant_ ,[1] an _acidity constant_[3] or
an _ionization constant_.[4] It serves as an indicator of the acid strength:
stronger acids have a higher _K_ a value (and a lower p _K_ a value).

##
Fragmentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Fragmentation")]

[Fragmentation](/wiki/Fragmentation_\(chemistry\) "Fragmentation
\(chemistry\)") of a molecule can take place by a process of
[heterolysis](/wiki/Heterolysis_\(chemistry\) "Heterolysis \(chemistry\)") or
[homolysis](/wiki/Homolysis_\(chemistry\) "Homolysis \(chemistry\)").

##
Receptors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dissociation_\(chemistry\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Receptors")]

[Receptors](/wiki/Receptor_\(biochemistry\) "Receptor \(biochemistry\)") are
[proteins](/wiki/Protein "Protein") that bind small [ligands](/wiki/Ligands
"Ligands"). The dissociation constant _K_ d is used as indicator of the
[affinity](/wiki/Affinity_\(pharmacology\) "Affinity \(pharmacology\)") of the
ligand to the receptor. The higher the affinity of the ligand for the receptor
the lower the _K_ d value (and the higher the p _K_ d value).
